October 22, 2019 at 3:28 PM ·

Mrs. Pruski's Art classes have been working on some amazing artwork!

The Shattered Glass Design was done by Art 1 students. They had to reveal an image using Chiaroscuro which controls light and darkness in value.

Art 2 created the Negative Space Collage with Watercolor. Students selected a variety of objects and arranged them to be visually appealing. Students then traced the contours of the shapes. In order to transfer the design, students used natural light from a window to trace onto other sheets. When finished, students painted the negative background space with watercolor.

Talented student artists make us Poth Proud!

Foggy conditions these past few mornings has made us more aware of the need for students and drivers to think SAFETY FIRST. POTH PROUD!!

TEXAS SCHOOL BUS LAW
•Stop for flashing red lights on a school bus
•Continue your trip once the bus has moved, the flashing lights stop flashing or the bus driver signals it's okay to pass.
•Violations can lead to a $1,000 fine.

TIPS FOR MOTORISTS
•Obey the posted speed limit and focus on the roadway.
•Fines double in school zones.
•Keep an eye on children gathered at bus stops.
•Watch for children who might dart across the street to catch the bus.

TIPS FOR STUDENTS
Respect your school bus driver and follow these rules:
•Stand far back when you are waiting for the bus.
•Sit still so the driver can pay attention to the road.
•Look both ways if you have to cross the street after getting off the bus, or wait for the driver to signal it's safe to cross the street.

Let’s do our part in ensuring the safety of all students and making sure they make it home safely at the end of each school day.

September 28, 2018 at 8:43 AM ·

Mrs. Luna's 7th grade science class conducted an experiment on Forces in Nature. The students soaked beans and then put them in a petri dish with cotton balls and paper towel to moisten them to get them to germinate. The petri dish allows the students to see which way the roots will grow. They determined the roots grew downward with the force of gravity. It allowed the classes to see “Geotropism.”

The “Plaster of Paris” in the cups allowed the science classes to observe the beans sprouting upward to see the effects of Negative Geotropism.

The students also hung them in a closet in a cabinet to see if sunlight or lack of had anything to do with germination. Results to come at a later date!

7th Grade Science students are Poth Proud!
